facts.text: The petitioners were arrested by P. N. Kalyankar, Sub-Inspector of Customs and Central Excise, on evidence of conspiracy to smuggle gold into Deogad port.

anchor.surface_text: Being in possession of evidence that the petitioners and others were companycerned in the companymission of offences of companyspiracy to smuggle gold from foreign companyntries into thE port of Deogad in the District of Ratnagiri, companytrary to the provisions of the Sea Customs Act and the Foreien Exchange Regulation Act, P. N.- Kalyankar, Sub-Inspector.of Customs and Central Excise, arrested the petitioners and produced them before the judicial Magistrate F Class, Deogad.

facts.text: Petitioners produced before judicial Magistrate F Class, Deogad after arrest.

anchor.surface_text: Being in possession of evidence that the petitioners and others were companycerned in the companymission of offences of companyspiracy to smuggle gold from foreign companyntries into thE port of Deogad in the District of Ratnagiri, companytrary to the provisions of the Sea Customs Act and the Foreien Exchange Regulation Act, P. N.- Kalyankar, Sub-Inspector.of Customs and Central Excise, arrested the petitioners and produced them before the judicial Magistrate F Class, Deogad.

facts.text: On December 29, 1961, Government of Maharashtra promulgated notification appointing V. M. Gehani as Special Judicial Magistrate for Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District with powers of Presidency Magistrate for Deogad Gold Seizure Case involving 49,990 tolas of gold.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1961, the Government of Maharashtra promulgated a numberification in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  as amended by Bombay Act XXIII of 1951 in its application to the State of Maharashtra  appointing Mr. V. M, Gehani to be a Special judicial Magistrate having jurisdiction over the area companyprising Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District, and companyferred upon him all the powers of a Presidency Magistrate in respect of the trial in the case involving the seizure of approximately 49,990 tolas of foreign gold and known as the Deogad Gold Seizure Case.

facts.text: On January 10, 1962, Government of Maharashtra gave consent under s.196A(2) CrPC for criminal proceedings against petitioners and eight others for offences under IPC s.120B r/w Sea Customs Act s.167(81), FERA s.8(1) and s.23.

anchor.surface_text: On January 10, 1962, the Government of Maharashtra gave companysent in writing as required by s. 196-A sub-section  2  of the Code of Criminal Procedure to the institution of criminal proceedings against the petitioners and eight others for offences punishable under s. 120B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 read with s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878  as amended  and s. 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878  as amended  and s. 8 1  of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act. 1947  as amended  and s. 120B of the Indian Penal Code read s. 8 1  with and s. 23 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947  as amended .

facts.text: H. R. Jokhi, Assistant Collector of Customs, instituted complaint against 16 persons including petitioners in court of Special Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter H. R. Jokhi, Assistant Collector of Customs Central Excise, Marine Prevention Division, Collectorate of Central Excise Bombay instituted a companyplaint in the Court of the Special Magistrate appointed under the Notification dated December 29, 1961, against 16 persons  including the petitioners  alleging that they were parties to a companyspiracy at Bombay, janjira, Dabhol and Deogad  the latter three places being in the District of Ratnagiri  and other places to smuggle large quantities of gold into India

facts.text: Complaint alleges conspiracy at Bombay, Janjira, Dabhol, Deogad and other places to smuggle gold from October 1959 to end of April 1961, acquiring 49,990 tolas gold valued at over Rs. 70,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that they were parties to a companyspiracy at Bombay, janjira, Dabhol and Deogad  the latter three places being in the District of Ratnagiri  and other places to smuggle large quantities of gold into India, with a view to evade or attempt to evade payment of duty thereon and to evade or attempt to evade the prohibition and restrictions in force relating thereto during the period from about October 1959 to the end of April 1961. or thereabout in breach of the provisions of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, and that the said persons had in pursuance of the companyspiracy and with companytinuing purpose and design in or about the month of April 1961 acquired or were companycerned in importing and acquiring possession, companytrary to the Sea Customs Act and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, gold totalling 49,990 tolas valued at over Rs. 70,00,000/-

facts.text: Petitioners are permanent residents of Deogad carrying on occupations there.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners applied to the Special Magistrate that they be tried at Deogad or at Ratangiri the headquarters of the District, for they were permanent residents of Deogad carrying on their respective occupations at Deogad, that they had already made their individual arrangements for their defence at Deogad and that it would be just and companyvenient that their trial should take place in the District of Ratnagiri.

facts.text: Petitioners applied to Special Magistrate for trial at Deogad or Ratnagiri, application rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners applied to the Special Magistrate that they be tried at Deogad or at Ratangiri the headquarters of the District, for they were permanent residents of Deogad carrying on their respective occupations at Deogad, that they had already made their individual arrangements for their defence at Deogad and that it would be just and companyvenient that their trial should take place in the District of Ratnagiri. The Magistrate rejected their appli- cation.

facts.text: Petitioners moved Bombay High Court for transfer of case to Deogad or Ratnagiri or direction to Special Magistrate to try there, application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then moved the High Court of judicature at Bombay praying for an order that the case against the petitioners be transferred for trial to the companyrt of some judicial Magistrate at Deogad or at Ratnagiri companypetent to try the case in the alternative the petitioners prayed that the Special Magistrate Mr. Gehani be directed to try the said case either at Deogad or at Ratnagiri at which place all facilities were available. The High Court dismissed their application.

facts.text: Petitioners filed Writ Petition under Art.32 in Supreme Court seeking quashing of notification dated Dec 29, 1961 or declaring s.14 CrPC amended by Bombay Act 23/1951 ultra vires, and trial at Deogad/Ratnagiri.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ PEtitioN No. 65 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the CoNstitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. ... The petitioners then moved this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ of certiorari or other appropriate writ or direction quashing the Notification dated December 29, 1961., issued by the Government of Maharashtra or in the alternative declaring s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Act 23 of 1951 ultra vires and void and for an order that the case be heard at Deogad or at Ratnagiri in the State of Maharashtra by any Magistrate companypetent to enquire into or try the case.

facts.text: Petitioners claim s.14 CrPC as amended and notification infringe Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: By this petition the petitioners submitted that s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Legislature by Act 23 of 1951 and the Notification dated December 29, 1961, issued by the Government of Maharashtra appointing Mr. Gehani as Special judicial Magistrate and investing him with the powers of a Presidency Magistrate, infringed Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra appointed Mr. Gehani with jurisdiction over Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1961, the Government of Maharashtra promulgated a numberification ... appointing Mr. V. M, Gehani to be a Special judicial Magistrate having jurisdiction over the area companyprising Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.14 CrPC as amended does not infringe Art.14, relying on M.K. Gopalan case.

anchor.surface_text: In M. K. Gopalan v. The state of Madhya Pradesh the validity of s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1898  V of 1898.  was challenged on the plea that it was void because it infringed the fundamental right of equality before the law guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution. This Court held that a law vesting discretion in an authority to appoint a Special Magistrate under s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to try cases entirely under the numbermal Procedure cannot be regarded as discriminatory and is number hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Notification upheld as valid constitution of Special Magistrate, not transfer of pending case.

A Notification Under s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is an order companystituting a Special Magistrate with jurisdiction over a certain local area and with powers which are numbermally exercisable by a Judicial Magistrate.

facts.text: Special Magistrate can sit at any place within his jurisdiction; no fixed place mandated.

facts.text: Bombay High Court rejected petitioners' transfer application due to alleged inconvenience.

issues.text: Whether s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Legislature by Act 23 of 1951 infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: By this petition the petitioners submitted that s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Legislature by Act 23 of 1951 and the Notification dated December 29, 1961, issued by the Government of Maharashtra appointing Mr. Gehani as Special judicial Magistrate and investing him with the powers of a Presidency Magistrate, infringed Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Notification under s.14 CrPC is unauthorised or tantamount to transfer of a pending case as in Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India

Whether the appointment of Special Magistrate with jurisdiction over Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District requiring possible trial in Bombay discriminates under Art.14 due to inconvenience and distance from Deogad
Whether conferring Presidency Magistrate powers on Special Magistrate discriminates under Art.14 by altering appeal forum to direct High Court appeal instead of Sessions Court

arguments.claim: s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Legislature by Act 23 of 1951 and the Notification dated December 29, 1961 infringed Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: By this petition the petitioners submitted that s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by the Bombay Legislature by Act 23 of 1951 and the Notification dated December 29, 1961, issued by the Government of Maharashtra appointing Mr. Gehani as Special judicial Magistrate and investing him with the powers of a Presidency Magistrate, infringed Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: On the principle of M. K. Gopalan's case, s. 14 as amended cannot be regarded as infringing Art. 14; vesting discretion not discriminatory

arguments.claim: In M. K. Gopalan v. State of Madhya Pradesh, s.14 CrPC held not to infringe Art.14; same applies here as no substantial difference post-amendment

anchor.surface_text: In M. K. Gopalan v. The state of Madhya Pradesh the validity of s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1898  V of 1898.  was challenged on the plea that it was void because it infringed the fundamental right of equality before the law guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Notification unauthorised relying on Bidi Supply Company v. Union of India as it amounts to transfer of pending case

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the judgment of this Court in Bidi Supply Company v. The Union of India  2 , it was submitted that the impugned Notification was unauthorised.

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle of Bidi Supply has no relevance; notification constitutes Special Magistrate, not transfer of pending case; s.14 covers future cases

arguments.claim: Notification under s.14 constitutes Special Magistrate with jurisdiction over local area including future cases, not transfer of pending case
Notification discriminatory under Art.14 as requires trial by Presidency Magistrate in Bombay, inconvenient for Deogad residents (>300 miles), unlike ordinary trial at offence place
arguments.court_reasoning: No provision fixes Magistrate sittings; Special Magistrate can sit anywhere in jurisdiction (Bombay + Ratnagiri); High Court rejected transfer on same ground

arguments.claim: No provision in CrPC requires Magistrate to hold sittings at particular place; s.9(2) only for Sessions Court; Special Magistrate discretion on place

arguments.court_reasoning: Not discrimination; incidental to powers conferred lawfully; direct HC appeal advantageous; depends on Magistrate class under s.182

arguments.claim: Difference in appeal forum arises from lawful conferral of Presidency powers on Special Magistrate, not unequal executive action

holdings.text: s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended, cannot be regarded as infringing Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle of M. K. Gopalans case  1 , s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended, cannot be regarded as infringing Art. 14 of the Constitution. Validity of the Notification issued by the Government of Maharashtra directing the trial by Mr. Gehani

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in M.K. Gopalan v. State of Madhya Pradesh holding that vesting discretion to appoint Special Magistrate under s.14 CrPC is not discriminatory under Art.14; no substantial difference post-Bombay amendment.

holdings.text: The Notification dated December 29, 1961 appointing Mr. V. M. Gehani as Special Judicial Magistrate is valid.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1961, the Government of Maharashtra promulgated a numberification in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 14 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  as amended by Bombay Act XXIII of 1951 in its application to the State of Maharashtra  appointing Mr. V. M, Gehani to be a Special judicial Magistrate having jurisdiction over the area companyprising Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri District, and companyferred upon him all the powers of a Presidency Magistrate in respect of the trial in the case involving the seizure of approximately 49,990 tolas of foreign gold and known as the Deogad Gold Seizure Case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Government competent under amended s.14 CrPC to appoint Special Magistrate with Presidency powers over specified local area (Greater Bombay and Ratnagiri); amendment removed prior prohibition on Presidency towns.

holdings.text: The Notification under s.14 CrPC constitutes a Special Magistrate and is not a transfer of a pending case; Bidi Supply Co. principle inapplicable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Bidi Supply (transfer of pending assessment under Income-tax Act) as s.14 notification creates jurisdiction for present/future cases, not transfers pending proceedings.

holdings.text: Appointment of Special Magistrate does not discriminate under Art.14 due to potential inconvenience of trial venue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No CrPC provision mandates fixed sitting place for Magistrates (unlike s.9(2) for Sessions); Special Magistrate may sit anywhere in jurisdiction (Bombay/Ratnagiri); High Court already rejected transfer on inconvenience; jurisdiction covers conspiracy/offence sites.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Art.14 in appeal forum arising from conferral of Presidency Magistrate powers on Special Magistrate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal route follows lawfully conferred powers (s.182 CrPC); direct High Court appeal advantageous; incidental to Magistrate class, not unequal executive action.
